page.title: 07EARLY DAYS AT ROSSINGTON PIT
page.content: Joseph Turner started work in 1917, aged 14, as a haulage hand. It was hard work, accidents were common but medical aid unheard of. Miners had to travel to the coalface in their own time carrying lamps, with food (snap) and drink tins (dudleys) strapped to their belts. Wearing boots,shorts and vests they worked waist deep in slurry using picks and shovels. With no pithead baths the men had to walk home filthy to wash. During the General Strike (1926) there was no strike pay and Joseph, newly married, had to sell possessions in order to live. Accidents and illness were feared as they could result in both loss of job and also the pit house that went with it. Joseph died from the miners' disease pneumoconiosis aged only 56.
